I would ask more of what is the advantage of Git. In order to effectively use Git in an org, what‚Äôs the first thing you do?  Setup a centralizer like GitHub, Bitbucket, etc.Perforce‚Äôs tooling is miles ahead of git imo. Beyond that, Perforce has a level of permanence that git doesn‚Äôt. One of the common themes in this thread is ‚Äúwell I have a full copy, so that‚Äôs safer‚Äù - but perforce is much more robust and has more info than git would keep anyway.Git promotes a broken model, in my opinion. It promotes working in isolation, and you are dependent on process to ensure code is merged and made visible frequently. It‚Äôs counter to the culture of CI and general collaboration you want in an enterprise.It‚Äôs great for open source. Beyond that, though, I‚Äôm not sure the following is warranted. It‚Äôs a fine tool, but I‚Äôm entirely unconvinced the system is really setup to foster the collaboration and permanence a big org really wants.

The advantage is work with just one branch - head(or main) is very simple and works great for very large code bases and thousands of developers in an enterprise. Perforce architecture fits very well in this. Git has a very fast merge model but doesn‚Äôt scale well for branching, originally it was designed for decentralized local coding

Hey corovan, would love to know where you ended up.

First off, smoke a ton of weed. The best advances in parallel and distributed computing have been from people when they're are at their most baked. If you can't do that for religious or personal reasons, data engineering probably isn't going to be the right path for you.Second off, dig into spark and some other common ETL frameworks and get a feel for writing programs on EMR and on virtual instances. You can do really small/low budget stuff if you keep your sizes tiny, but use a couple machines at least. Do a few parallelized ML algorithms and consider reading the spark data engineer book. Visualize some of the stuff you do. Build a tiny GitHub resume of spark apps made for funsies.After that, you should just focus on getting your piss clear from the weed so you can try your hand at a couple of interviews.

Learn a programming language and try to implement the ETL modules yourself, try a different architecture like ELT or Streaming, dimensional modeling, analytical work, data visualization. The field is massive.
Learn a programming language, that's needed for post cloud ETL

350k to 400k is going to be tough. Don‚Äôt go by all the FAANG offers you see around here. That‚Äôs not the norm and more of an exception, even in bay area.Is your 14 years of experience in some specialized field like ML, DL, Computer vision? Even if not specialized, do you have tons of experience in distributed systems? Because most of the web companies that do tend to pay those high salaries works a lot on distributed systems.At 14 years, just doing LC wont be enough. You ll be grilled on system design, and expected to know how to design large scale distributed systems. Reading about things is a good start, but that wont replace real experience. You ll be competing with candidates who are 3-5 years out of college, and have real experience in distributed systems.I think LC is a good start, but get your expectations right and try to first get into a right job.

You need to be comfortable with a programming language to be able to target other tech roles. I suggest Python, it‚Äôs very beginner friendly. For Data heavy roles: add data pipleine building stuff (luigi, airflow, pandas, spark). For Software engineering, leetcode and system design. There are also pre sales tech roles with azure/aws/gcp. You need to have one or two good verticals (databases and programming could be that) and some high level knowledge in others like networks, storage, architecture. Look for Solutiom architect or customer engineer interview question. If you target amazon, learn their cloud offerings in that specific domain: EMR, s3, redshift... etc
